summary: TGEV is an animal coronavirus that causes severe gastroenteritis in young pigs. mortality rate for piglets under 2 weeks of age is the highest, reaching almost 100%. pigs often present with vomiting, dehydration, and severe diarrhea. transmembrane protein acts as a minor structural component in TGEV. it is infectious and invades the organism through the digestive and respiratory tracts. these changes are known to be important during the pathogenesis of TGEV infection. a recent study indicates that plasmid-transcribed small hairpin (sh) RNAs targeting the ORF7 gene of TGEV is capable of inhibiting virus replication and expression of the viral target gene in ST cells in vitro [15]. a recent study indicates that plasmid-transcribed small hairpin (sh) RNAs targeting the ORF7 gene of TGEV is capable of inhibiting virus replication and expression of the viral target gene in ST cells in vitro. isobaric tags for relative and absolute quantitation (iTRAQ) technique is a more advanced method for proteomic research. it is capable of detecting a much larger number of proteins, even those with low abundance. to this end, Lu et al. previously used the iTRAQ method to identify 160 significantly altered proteins in pulmonary alveolar macrophages infected with PRRSV. TGEV infection The monolayer of confluent ST cells was dispersed with 0.25% trypsin and 0.02% ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) the cells were then infected with the TGEV TH-98 strain at a 50% tissue culture infectious dose (TCID50) of 1103.53 viruses per well, with absorption for 2 h at 37°C. RT reaction was incubated at 37°C for 15 min followed by 85°C for 5 s. a mixture of oligo dT primers and random 6 mers was used in the RT step. cDNA was stored at 20°C until further use. the cycling conditions were 94°C for 4 min followed by 35 cycles of 94°C for 20 s, 60°C for 30 s, 72°C for 30 s, and then a final extension of 10 min at 72°C. the relative gene expression was determined with the 2(Ct) method [28] and the tests were performed in triplicate. 2D LC-MS/MS analysis The combined peptide mixtures were separated by reversed phase high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) on a Durashell-C18 reverse phase column (4.6 mm 250 mm, 5 m 100, Agela) the mobile phases used were composed of 20 mM ammonium formate (pH 10) in water (labeled mobile phase A) and 20 mM ammonium formate (pH 10) in acetonit data analysis and bioinformatics Protein identification and quantification were performed with the ProteinPilot software (version 4.0, AB Sciex) each MS/MS spectrum was searched against a database of Sus scrofa protein sequences (NCBI nr, released in March 2011) the protein-protein interaction network for a select group of proteins was analyzed using the STRING 9.1 database. the protein-protein interaction network for a select group of proteins was analyzed using the STRING 9.1 database. anti-caspase 8 antibody (1300; abcam, Cambridge, UK) overnight at 4°C, followed by HRP-conjugated secondary antibody (15000; Western Biotechnology, China) for 1.5 h at 37°C. membranes were then washed four times in TBST buffer for 5 min each time. a mock group of ST cells that were not infected with TGEV was added to the cells. three replicates of virus-infected and mock-infected cultures were prepared. the morphological changes were observed at 24, 40, 48, and 64 hours post infection. RT-PCR products were resolved on a 15 g/L agarose gel. a final extension step was carried out at 72 C for 10 min. a final extension step was carried out at 72 C for 10 min. the soluble protein fraction was harvested by centrifugation at 40,000 g for 30 min at 4°C. a 100 g aliquot of protein from each sample was reduced, alkylated, and trypsin-digested. two virus-free samples at 48 h and 64 h were labeled with iTRAQ tags 114 and 115. the elutant was collected into 48 centrifuge tubes at each minute after the first 5 min. each aliquot was then dried by vacuum freezing. the peptides were then analyzed with a nanoflow reversed-phase liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (nano-RPLC-MS/MS) system. iTRAQ 4-plex (peptide labeled), cysteine alkylation with methyl methanethiosulfonate(MMTS), trypsin digestion, biological modifications allowed. a thorough search, a detected protein threshold of 95% confidence (unused Protscore 1.3) and a critical false discovery rate (FDR) of 1% were used. membranes were incubated with anti-glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH) mouse monoclonal antibody (13000; Western Biotechnology, China), anti-heat shock protein 90 alpha (Hsp90/HSP90AA1) antibody (1300; Abcam, Cambridge, UK) overnight at 4°C, followed by HRP-conjugate secondary antibody (15000; Western Biotechnology, China) for 1.5 h at 37°C. cytopathic effects (CPEs) were imaged at 24 (A), 40 (B), 48 (C) and 64 (D) hours after infection. qRT-PCR analysis of changes in mRNA expression levels in ST cells. the average Ct value for the -actin control gene ranged from 19.6 to 27.5. the relative expression of TGEV N mRNA was calculated using the 2(–CT) method [28], and the change in expression at each time point is indicated in Figure 2B. differentially expressed proteins identified were considered to show a significant upward or downward trend if their expression ratios were greater than 4.0 or less than 0.25 compared to the control group. iTRAQ ratios higher than 3.3475 (p = 0.975) or lower than 1.3475 (p = 0.025) were defined as statistically significant. gi|359811347 60 kDa heat shock protein, mitochondrial – 139.52 3.16 0.00 hpi. the final step of our GO enrichment analysis consisted of investigating the mechanistic role these genes play in the cell. at 48 hpi, the most enriched biological process was related to cell recognition during phagocytosis(p = 8.02E-1). the majority proteins in these protein networks, such as radical S-adenosyl methionine domain containing protein 2 (RSAD2), Mx dynamin-like GTPase 1 (Mx1), 2′-5′-oligoadenylate synthetase 1 (OAS1), Mx dynamin- the significance of the GO biological process is derived from the network in Figure 4B and was determined using the FDR correction (p0.05). western blot confirmation of altered expression for three of the differentially expressed proteins was performed to further confirm the proteomic data for three of the proteins. integrated optical density (IOD) analysis showed an upregulation of caspase-8 (1.27 fold) and TGF-1 (3.08 fold), but HSP90 was almost unchanged (0.90 fold) at 64 hpi (I64), we observed an upregulation in both caspase-8 (3.11 fold) and TGF-1 (4.58 fold), but a 5.82 fold downregulation of HSP90. qRT-PCR analysis of changes in mRNA expression levels in the ST cells. the changes in mRNA expression level at the various time points is indicated. the expression level of TGEV increased gradually, reaching a peak at 48 h, then decreased dramatically. alterations in protein abundance due to virus infection were near-linear dependency between the two time points. iTRAQ ratios higher than 3.3475 (p = 0.975) or lower than 1.3475 (p = 0.025) were defined as statistically significant. a total of 316 unique proteins were significantly different between the two time points (54 upregulated and 18 downregulated), resulting in a total of 162 predicted proteins. the current pig genome database is poorly annotated compared to the human genome database. however, our ability to detect the unannotated proteins by MS demonstrates that they do existence in this species. kDa protein 1B HSPA1B 62.37 4.33 PN-1, VDAC a cellular component-based enrichment analysis was performed at 48 hpi. at 48 hpi, we observed significant enrichments in extracellular region. 37 differentially expressed proteins were significantly enriched at 64 hpi. GO enrichment analysis for the STRING protein network at 64 hpi showed several biological processes were significantly affected. at 48 hpi, the most enriched biological process was related to cell recognition during phagocytosis(p = 8.02E-1). GO biological process P-value Regulation of viral genome replication 1.33E-2 Innate immune response 1.35E-2 Negative regulation of viral genome replication 2.36E-2 Regulation of viral process 2.70E-2 Negative regulation of viral process 2.83E-2 ATP biosynthetic process 2.89E-2 Note: the significance of the GO biological process is derived from the network in Figure 4B. western blot confirmation for three differentially expressed proteins during TGEV infection. equal amounts of protein were separated by SDS-PAGE and transferred to PVDF membranes. membranes were then probed with the specified antibody. the iTRAQ technique has been widely used for quantitative proteomics. the results indicated that TGEV induced significant CPEs from 40 to 64 hpi in infected cells compared to the mock infected cells. at 48 hpi more than 80% infected cells showed rounding and granular degeneration. expression level of HSP90 expression was unchanged at 48 hpi, but decreased at 64 hpi. 316 altered proteins also includes proteins that changed from 48 hpi to 64 hpi. mitochondrial aldehyde dehydrogenase 2 (ALDH2) and MHC class I antigen (PD1) were not changed at 48 or 64 hpi compared to the 48 hpi time point in infected ST cells. 15 proteins involved in cell death pathways had significantly altered expression levels (p = 4.46E-2), including melanoma differentiation associated protein-5 (MDA5), monocyte chemoattractant protein 1 (CCL2), thioredoxin- dependent peroxide reductase, mitochondrial (PRDX3), peroxiredoxin-2 (PRDX2), predicted protein CYR61 (CYR61), keratin, type II cytoskeletal 8 (KRT serine/threonine-protein phosphatase PP1-beta-catalytic subunit (PPP1CB), scavenger receptor class B member 1 (SCARB1), transforming growth factor-beta-induced protein ig-h3 and predicted inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate receptor type 3 (ITPR3) were uniquely altered, likely indicating changes in cell adhesion and/or cell-cell signaling processes. HSP90 is one of the most abundant molecular chaperones that is induced in response to cellular stress. it functions to stabilize proteins involved in cell growth and anti-apoptotic signaling. reduction of HSP90 has been reported to decrease correct assembly of human enterovirus 71 viral particles. a recent study showed that HSP70 is an essential host factor for the replication of PRRSV. a recent study showed that the silence of HSP70 significantly reduced PRRSV replication. we speculate that these proteins play a potential role in TGEV replication. the upregulation of the TGF- may impair the host immune response during PRRSV infection by limiting the overproduction of proinflammatory cytokines necessary to decrease PRRSV replication. interferon-inducible antiviral proteins, RSAD2, OAS1, were also upregulated in the period of late infection.
